results.title: Spread your wings: making it with TAFE
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films, Technical and Further Education, Chris Stewart and John O'Shea
results.brief_description: An impressionistic film which is intended to provide information about the opportunities offered by Technical and Further Education in vocational training, and in recreational courses to meet community requirements. It is not intended to give detailed information on the breadth of courses and curricula but is rather a stimulus film aimed at encouraging enrolment.

results.title: Evaluation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Depicts a school that takes its evaluation seriously. Keeping in touch with its community has required constant monitoring and some innovative adjustments. Staff, curriculum, in service and Supplementary Grants meetings are now one and the same and are occasions where parents and teachers learn together.

results.title: Indonesia: an Alternative Lifestyle
results.creator_credit: Experimental Film and Television Fund and Leigh Tilson
results.brief_description: A non-narrated film that contrasts behind-the-scenes life in both rural and urban Indonesia with the view of the country as seen by foreign tourists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Experimental Film and Television Fund and Leigh Tilson

results.title: In the Wake of the Stars
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Bede Whiteman and Mark McDonald
results.brief_description: Aviation came quickly in Australia. In the early days reliable DC3’s carried everyone and everything. Then new faster and more comfortable aircraft were sought: the Fokker Friendship from Holland, the super Viscount from France and turbo jets from America. During training flights the attractions of gracious Amsterdam, gay Paris, England’s spring, New York’s people, Rome’s buildings and Australia’s scenic attractions are presented.

results.title: Community College Mt Gambier: growing
results.creator_credit: New Films, South Australian Film Corporation and Justin Milne
results.brief_description: This is the story of the South East Community College Mount Gambier. Features two teachers, Bev Puckridge and Ian Winter, who narrate throughout the film. Shows how students go back to their own communities and set up and teach smaller groups in woodwork, pottery, spinning etc. Emphasis is made that art is a natural part of our world - a natural thing to do. It is not the finished product that really matters, but the thought process used to achieve it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: New Films, South Australian Film Corporation and Justin Milne

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → 05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-C03

results.title: Daybill for the American release of Jedda
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.
results.description: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.
description_for_label: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.
